text: <@UJJELJPNH> this is the main group and then there are a lot of more niche groups for specific industries or types of writing: <https://m.facebook.com/groups/1983851761839133|https://m.facebook.com/groups/1983851761839133>

attachments.title: Binders Full of WRITING JOBS Public Group | Facebook
attachments.text: Binders Full of WRITING JOBS has 28,550 members. PURPOSE: Welcome! This group is for WOMEN and gender non-conforming writers of all backgrounds to share freelance, part-time, and full-time PAID opportunities for fellow women writers/editors. DO: *Post job opportunities you hear about through colleagues or come across elsewhere. *If you're an editor or "boss," feel free to post opportunities within your publications *Share tips about finding jobs, as well as negotiating salaries/rates *Whenever possible, please label opportunity as junior, mid-level, or senior and provide an idea of compensation PLEASE: *Use your discretion. This is a secret group, but members are free to add other members. * Do NOT post unpaid work -- we need to pay our bills and know that our time worth so much more. *Be respectful. *Don’t post anyone's contact information without their express consent. *Do not share these opportunities outside the group without prior permission *Don't post unrelated material or spam the group. *Keep in mind that this group is for sharing opportunities, not self-promotion. This group is maintained by @mysteriouskat and is an offspring of the original Binders of Women Full of Writers. It is sub-moderated by Jamila Bey & Seánan Forbes.

files.name: Marketing_in_the_time_of_COVID-19
files.title: Marketing in the time of COVID-19
files.preview:
We've all been trying to figure out how marketing shifts during this time. My head has been very much in this space as we cancelled a big event lineup and refunded...so much ticket revenue....I wanted to share a few things I'm thinking about/observing. I would love to hear what others think.

The big one is this: let's think about people, not clicks.

Here's where I'm coming from...

We have a pretty large Slack community around our product, and a few people in the group started talking about arranging Zoom checkins with each other. People are alienated and anxious all day right now, but they're still working and looking to other people in their industry for support.

We opened up a new Slack channel with one of our partners across the company. The energy in that space feels so good as we plan how to work together and commiserate (How does it feel where you are??). This is a company we've been working with for a long time, but for some reason now feels the right time to get a little closer (on Slack, not IRL! :mask:)

We're trying to figure out how to shift a two-day, in-person training program to a multi-day online program. I contacted a former co-worker who runs a ton of Zoom trainings and he got on a call with my team to give us advice on how to do this really well. It was so.fun.

Our CEO has made it abundantly clear that everyone's productivity is going to suffer during this time and that is OK. We should be focusing on caring for our families and community. We're all a little less busy, a little more focused on the things that really matter. A lot more...tense.

All of these things have made it clear to me that this is the time to be connecting with people. If you're thinking about how to use this time to generate clicks for your blog, you have completely missed the point. We are all unusually vulnerable right now. Use this time to be honest, unpolished, supportive. To your friends, family, and also your customers and work community.

Have long, rambling calls with co-workers. Be unproductive. Care for the people you love. Catch up with that old mentor. Brainstorm with a partner. Invite your customers to an informal chat with your product manager. Give yourself space to do work that's just less...markety.

This is a community I'm looking forward to hearing more from over the coming weeks as I try to do my job and manage my own anxiety (omg, we're closing on a house in two weeks...how is that for bad timing?!).

Stay safe & healthy :heart:
~Janessa

text:
Really well said Janessa, thanks for sharing.

One of my best friends works for an SF tech company that could easily have shifted to remote by now but isn’t pulling the trigger. The CEO just held a tone deaf all hands that was all about how they can maintain productivity and reach their Q2 goals.

I am fortunate to work for a super supportive fully remote company already, and I want to at least be a resource / person to commiserate with for those who are in way more challenging situations.

text: That's awful. The Q2 goals of your tech company are so unimportant right now. Let's get some perspective.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text: You being the CEO...not you... Drew
Just to be clear

text: We've taken more of a tone of "how can we help?". Our next weekly email is literally that question. Basically we don't want to put out anything that doesn't come directly from what our audience is looking for right now. We also put all of our automated social posting on hold and will only be doing manual posting for at least the next two weeks to prevent any tone-deaf promotion. Thoughts on this approach?

text: I wrote this silly piece of content inspired by some of the threads I've seen on what marketers and PR people should, and should not, do in this time. I get it if it's informational or to waive late fees, but if it's junk mail, I don't want it!

elements.text: I wrote this silly piece of content inspired by some of the threads I've seen on what marketers and PR people should, and should not, do in this time. I get it if it's informational or to waive late fees, but if it's junk mail, I don't want it!

text:
MAD LIBS: IMPORTANT EMAILS FROM BRANDS ABOUT CORONAVIRUS
Email Subject: An important COVID-19 message from our [c-suite job title]
Dear [First name of a friend],
I'm reaching out to you on behalf of [Name of Company] to connect with you about the ongoing [Favorite brand of beer]-virus pandemic that has been sweeping [country] faster than a [type of animal] looking for [a snack food, plural].
As you know, this [negative adjective] virus isn't going anywhere fast. That's why we at [Same company] are taking extra precautionary measures to [positive verb] and [negative verb].
Now and always, our commitment to the health and safety of your [body part] and [another body part] remains of paramount importance. That's why we are monitoring this evolving [scary animal] of a situation to provide you with industry-leading actions and protocols.
We have taken these additional precautions to [verb] your [increment of time]:
1) Introduced three extra [plural noun] per day at every [type of vehicle]
2) Elevated frequency of [gerund phrase] throughout the week
3) Mandated handwashing for all [plural animal] and robots
Thank you for your patience in these [negative adjective] times, and we appreciate your [positive adjective] business.
Don't forget to [verb] your [body part] and wash your hands!
In health,
[Another first name]
[C-suite job title], [Same company]
